data.title: Best Looking 3 Stooges Babe
data.text:
oblivion stated:

One of my

favorite supporting actresses is Ann Doran. She handles the silliness

wonderfully (and she's not bad to look at either).

I love watching those three girls do the dance number in "Rhythm and

Weep". Man oh man!

Dorothy Granger is lovely in "Punch Drunks". And is that also her

in "Termites of 1938" ("Clayhammer!!")?

In the Shemp shorts, I like Connie Cezan (I talked to her on the phone

once!).

-----

Is Connie still with us? I know Ann Doran is (and, sadly, Ms. Granger is not)

JN

"The most contagious thing in the world is enthusiasm."

Yes that was Dorothy in "Termites of 1938". She appeared in 112 films,

mostly as a bit character player. Some of them you will readily

remember.

1930 "The Laurel and Hardy Murder Case"

1935 "Naughty Marietta" with Nelson Eddy and Jeanette McDonald

1947 The Secret Life of Walter Mitty" with Danny Kaye and Virginia

Mayo

1948 The Paleface" with Bob Hope and Jane Russell

She also played the wife of Leon Errol in a long running two reeler

series for RKO

She won a beauty contest at the age of 13 in Texas.

Her last public appearance was in 1993 when the Screen Actors Guild

honored its character members who had been issued SAG cards when Sag

was founded sixty years ago.

She passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 82 of cancer in 1995

She was one of my favorites too, if you watch, you will see her as a

bit player in lots of the old movies. I have been watching movies

since I was 8 and I am 65 now. Lots of memorable times.

On Sun, 30 May 1999 03:34:01 GMT, oblivion <obli...@nls.net> wrote:

>There are so many gorgeous girls in the Stooges' shorts! One of my

>favorite supporting actresses is Ann Doran. She handles the silliness

>wonderfully (and she's not bad to look at either).

> I love watching those three girls do the dance number in "Rhythm and

>Weep". Man oh man!

> Dorothy Granger is lovely in "Punch Drunks". And is that also her

>in "Termites of 1938" ("Clayhammer!!")?

> In the Shemp shorts, I like Connie Cezan (I talked to her on the phone

>once!).

>

>Joe

î—“
